bibl.title: Letter from Austin Smith to Philip Showalter Hench, December 16, 1952

div1.p: Smith accepts Hench's offer to document the Camp Lazear dedication as if he were the correspondent for the “Journal of the American Medical Association.” He inquires if Hench knows of someone in Cuba who would be willing to be a correspondent for the journal.

div1.head: Letter from Austin Smith to Philip Showalter Hench, December 16, 1952
div1.opener:
EDITOR
AUSTIN SMITH, M.D.
The Journal of the
American Medical Association
535 North Dearborn Street
Chicago 10
December 16, 1952
ASSOCIATE EDITORS
JOHNSON F. HAMMOND, M.D.
GEORGE HALPERIN, M.D.
In your reply please
refer to these initials
AS:P
Dr. P. S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p: I appreciate very much your letter of December 12.

Frankly, I would like to take your second suggestion--
that is, that you write up the affair as if you were our
Havana correspondent. I think that we can safely wait until
after the end of the year before we publish something in
THE JOURNAL. It will be just as interesting then as it
would be this week or next.

Incidentally, I have been trying for two or three years
to get a correspondent in Havana to give us a letter once a
month for publication in THE JOURNAL. It does not have to
be long, but I feel that it would be good for the medical
profession in both countries if we could develop such a
liaison. To be perfectly frank, I have found that “mañana”
is just as important in Cuba as in some other Latin areas
and so far have not got a satisfactory response. I wonder
if you know anyone who has had a transfusion from the northern
climate and is sufficiently pepped up to do something like
that regularly.

I am sorry that the A.M.A. representative arrived so
late, but the whole affair was arranged hurriedly, as I was
going to be out of town, Doctor Lull would be out of town and
Dr. Louis Bauer would not be here. Knowing Doctor Chrisman,
I suggested him as a representative, but the arrangements were
still being completed at the last minute.

I feel that you should not be asked to bear the expense
of purchasing a wreath and therefore ask you to let me know
at your earliest convenience how much it cost you. We cer-
tainly want to reimburse you.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, Austin Smith, M. D. MP
